message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Krylov complexity as an order parameter for quantum chaotic-integrable transitions
Paper Abstract: Krylov complexity has recently emerged as a new paradigm to characterize quantum chaos in many-body systems. However, which features of Krylov complexity are a prerogative of quantum chaotic systems and how they relate to more standard probes, such as spectral statistics or out-of-time-order correlators (OTOCs), remain open questions. Recent insights have revealed that in quantum chaotic systems Krylov state complexity exhibits a distinct peak during time evolution before settling into a well-understood late-time plateau. In this work we propose that this Krylov complexity peak (KCP) is a hallmark of quantum chaotic systems and suggest that its height could serve as an order parameter for quantum chaos. We demonstrate that the KCP effectively identifies chaotic-integrable transitions in two representative quantum-mechanical models at both infinite and finite temperature: the mass-deformed Sachdev-Ye-Kitaev model and the sparse Sachdev-Ye-Kitaev model. Our findings align with established results from spectral statistics and OTOCs while introducing an operator-independent diagnostic for quantum chaos, offering more universal insights and a deeper understanding of the general properties of quantum chaotic systems.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

## Results for "Out-of-Time-Order Correlators"

Based on the search results, here's what I found about out-of-time-order correlators (OTOCs):

### Basic Definition and Application

In thermalizing systems, the dynamics of out-of-time-ordered correlators forms a linear light cone which reflects the ballistic propagation of information. This is a key concept in studying how information spreads through quantum systems.

### Use in Many-Body Localization

One important application of OTOCs is in studying many-body localization (MBL). In MBL systems, the light cone is logarithmic. This difference in light cone behavior between thermalizing and MBL systems is used as a signature to distinguish between these two different phases of quantum matter.

### Context with Other Correlators

While the search results don't provide extensive detail specifically about OTOCs, they do note that in quantum field theory, correlation functions, often referred to as correlators or Green's functions, are vacuum expectation values of time-ordered products of field operators. Out-of-time-order correlators are a distinct type that involves operators arranged in a non-standard time ordering, which makes them sensitive to information scrambling and chaos in quantum systems.

OTOCs have become increasingly important in quantum information theory and condensed matter physics for understanding quantum chaos, thermalization, and information dynamics in many-body systems.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Percival - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ian_C._Percival"},{"title":"File:Quantum Chaos.jpg - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Quantum_Chaos.jpg"}]

## Quantum Chaos - Overview

Quantum chaos is a branch of physics focused on how chaotic classical dynamical systems can be described in terms of quantum theory.(no content)The primary question that quantum chaos seeks to answer is: "What is the relationship between quantum mechanics and classical chaos?"

### Key Concepts

Classical-quantum correspondence in chaos theory is not always possible, and some versions of the classical butterfly effect do not have counterparts in quantum mechanics.(no content)Important observations often associated with classically chaotic quantum systems are spectral level repulsion, dynamical localization in time evolution (e.g. ionization rates of atoms), and enhanced stationary wave intensities in regions of space where classical dynamics exhibits only unstable trajectories.

### Research Approaches

Several approaches have been employed to address quantum chaos, including development of methods for solving quantum problems where perturbation theory doesn't apply and quantum numbers are large, correlating statistical descriptions of eigenvalues with classical behavior, studying probability distribution of individual eigenstates, and using semiclassical methods such as periodic-orbit theory.

### Notable Figures

Boris Chirikov was the founder of the physical theory of Hamiltonian chaos and made pioneering contributions to the theory of quantum chaos.(no content)Eric J. Heller is known for his work on quantum chaos, particularly on scar theory.

Web search results for query: "order parameter physics"

Links: [{"title":"Phase transition - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Phase_transition"},{"title":"Landau theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Landau_theory"},{"title":"Order and disorder - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Order_and_disorder"},{"title":"Universality class - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ising_critical_exponents"},{"title":"Topological order - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Topological_order"},{"title":"Order operator - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Order_operator"},{"title":"Path-ordering - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Path-ordering"},{"title":"Classical XY model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Classical_XY_model"},{"title":"Perturbation theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Perturbation_theory"},{"title":"Ginzburg–Landau theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ginzburg–Landau_theory"}]

Based on the search results, here's an overview of the order parameter in physics:

## Definition

An order parameter is a measure of the degree of order across the boundaries in a phase transition system; it normally ranges between zero in one phase (usually above the critical point) and nonzero in the other.

## Key Characteristics

The order parameter is a measure of the order before and after a phase transition; the order parameter is often zero above some critical temperature and non-zero below the critical temperature.(no content)At the critical point, the order parameter susceptibility will usually diverge.

## Symmetry and Theory

From a theoretical perspective, order parameters arise from symmetry breaking. When this happens, one needs to introduce one or more extra variables to describe the state of the system.

## Examples

An example of an order parameter is the net magnetization in a ferromagnetic system undergoing a phase transition.(no content)For liquid/gas transitions, the order parameter is the difference of the densities.

## Quantum Field Theory

In quantum field theory, an order operator or an order field is a quantum field version of Landau's order parameter whose expectation value characterizes phase transitions.

The order parameter is a fundamental concept in understanding phase transitions and the behavior of physical systems across different states.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Links: [{"title":"Spectral analysis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spectral_analysis"},{"title":"Spectral density estimation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spectral_density_estimation"},{"title":"Random matrix - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Random_matrix"},{"title":"Spectral density - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spectral_density"},{"title":"Spectral test - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spectral_test"},{"title":"Singular spectrum analysis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Singular_spectrum_analysis"},{"title":"Spectral power distribution - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spectral_power_distribution"},{"title":"Least-squares spectral analysis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Least-squares_spectral_analysis"},{"title":"Spectral risk measure - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spectral_risk_measure"},{"title":"Noise (spectral phenomenon) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Noise_(spectral_phenomenon)"}]

Based on the search results, here's information about spectral statistics:

## Overview

"Spectral statistics" refers to several related concepts depending on the context:

### Spectral Density and Analysis

In statistical signal processing, spectral density estimation (SDE) or spectral estimation is the process of estimating the spectral density (also known as power spectral density) of a signal from time samples. The statistical average of the energy or power of any type of signal (including noise) as analyzed in terms of its frequency content is called its spectral density.

The spectral density characterizes the frequency content of the signal, and one purpose of estimating it is to detect any periodicities in the data by observing peaks at the frequencies corresponding to these periodicities.

### Methods and Techniques

Spectral estimation techniques can generally be divided into non-parametric, parametric, and more recently semi-parametric (sparse) methods. Common techniques include Welch's method, which is widely used for spectral density estimation, as well as approaches like the periodogram, singular spectrum analysis, and autoregressive models.

### Random Matrix Theory

In a different context, random matrix theory is used to study the spectral properties of random matrices—such as sample covariance matrices—which is of particular interest in high-dimensional statistics.

### Other Applications

The term is also used in specialized contexts such as the spectral test, which is a statistical test for the quality of pseudorandom number generators, and spectral risk measures, which are risk measures given as weighted averages of outcomes for portfolio analysis.

Based on the web search results, here's information about the Sachdev-Ye-Kitaev model:

## Overview

The Sachdev–Ye–Kitaev (SYK) model is an exactly solvable model initially proposed by Subir Sachdev and Jinwu Ye, and later modified by Alexei Kitaev to the present commonly used form.

## Applications and Significance

The model is believed to bring insights into the understanding of strongly correlated materials and it also has a close relation with the discrete model of AdS/CFT.(no content)Many condensed matter systems, such as quantum dot coupled to topological superconducting wires, graphene flake with irregular boundary, and kagome optical lattice with impurities, are proposed to be modeled by it.

## Experimental Progress

Some variants of the model are amenable to digital quantum simulation, with pioneering experiments implemented in nuclear magnetic resonance.

## Quantum Information Connection

A connection between the structure of quantum entanglement in the SYK model and in black holes was first proposed by Sachdev in 2010, and these connections have led to developments in the quantum theory of black holes.

The SYK model has become an important tool for understanding quantum entanglement, quantum criticality, and the connections between condensed matter physics and gravitational physics through the AdS/CFT correspondence.

Web search results for query: "quantum integrable systems"

Links: [{"title":"Integrable system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Integrable_system"},{"title":"List of integrable models - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_integrable_models"},{"title":"Constant of motion - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Constants_of_motion"},{"title":"Action-angle coordinates - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Action-angle_coordinates"},{"title":"Nicolai Reshetikhin - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nicolai_Reshetikhin"},{"title":"List of quantum-mechanical systems with analytical solutions - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_quantum_mechanical_systems_with_analytical_solutions"},{"title":"Category:Integrable systems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Integrable_systems"},{"title":"Nikita Nekrasov - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nikita_Nekrasov"},{"title":"Quantum ergodicity - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quantum_ergodicity"},{"title":"Geometric quantization - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Geometric_quantization"}]

Here are the search results for "quantum integrable systems":

## Overview

A quantum system is said to be integrable if the dynamics are two-body reducible.(no content)In general, an integrable system has constants of motion other than the energy. By contrast, energy is the only constant of motion in a non-integrable system; such systems are termed chaotic.

## Key Characteristics

The Yang–Baxter equation is a consequence of this reducibility and leads to trace identities which provide an infinite set of conserved quantities.(no content)Three features are often referred to as characterizing integrable systems: the existence of a maximal set of conserved quantities (the usual defining property of complete integrability) the existence of algebraic invariants, having a basis in algebraic geometry (a property known sometimes as algebraic integrability) the explicit determination of solutions in an explicit functional form (not an intrinsic property, but something often referred to as solvability)

## Examples and Methods

Examples of quantum integrable models are the Lieb–Liniger model, the Hubbard model and several variations on the Heisenberg model.(no content)Two closely related methods: the Bethe ansatz approach, in its modern sense, based on the Yang–Baxter equations and the quantum inverse scattering method, provide quantum analogs of the inverse spectral methods.

## Significance

There are relatively few models in physics which have non-linear terms or couplings, and can still be solved exactly (that is, without resorting to perturbation theory); thus, such models are celebrated.

Based on the search results, here's an overview of many-body systems:

## Definition

The quantum many-body problem is a general name for a vast category of physical problems pertaining to deriving the behavior of multi-particle systems using fundamental quantum-mechanical principles.

## Key Challenges

One of the primary difficulties with many-body systems is computational complexity. Because the required numerical expense grows so quickly, simulating the dynamics of more than three quantum-mechanical particles is already infeasible for many physical systems.(no content)It ranks among the most computationally intensive fields of science.(no content)Many-body physics most often relies on a set of approximation methods, such as the variational method and perturbation theory, specific to the problem at hand.

## Importance and Applications

Many-body problems play a central role in condensed matter physics. This field covers areas including solid-state physics, nanoscience, and superconductivity.

## Related Phenomena

An important area of research is many-body localization (MBL). Many-body localization is a dynamical phenomenon occurring in isolated many-body quantum systems, characterized by the system failing to reach thermal equilibrium, and retaining a memory of its initial condition in local observables for infinite times.

Web search results for query: "SYK model Sachdev Ye Kitaev"

Links: [{"title":"Sachdev–Ye–Kitaev model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sachdev–Ye–Kitaev_model"},{"title":"Subir Sachdev - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Subir_Sachdev"},{"title":"Alexei Kitaev - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alexei_Kitaev"},{"title":"SYK - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SYK"},{"title":"Solovay–Kitaev theorem - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Solovay–Kitaev_theorem"},{"title":"Kitaev chain - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kitaev_chain"},{"title":"Sergey Kitaev - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sergey_Kitaev"},{"title":"Gottesman–Kitaev–Preskill code - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gottesman%E2%80%93Kitaev%E2%80%93Preskill_code"},{"title":"Tyrosine-protein kinase SYK - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Syk_inhibitor"},{"title":"Shashwat Sachdev - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shashwat_Sachdev"}]

Here are the search results for the SYK model (Sachdev-Ye-Kitaev model):

## Overview

The Sachdev–Ye–Kitaev (SYK) model is an exactly solvable model initially proposed by Subir Sachdev and Jinwu Ye, and later modified by Alexei Kitaev to the present commonly used form.

## Applications and Significance

The model is believed to bring insights into the understanding of strongly correlated materials and it also has a close relation with the discrete model of AdS/CFT.(no content)Many condensed matter systems, such as quantum dot coupled to topological superconducting wires, graphene flake with irregular boundary, and kagome optical lattice with impurities, are proposed to be modeled by it.(no content)A connection between the structure of quantum entanglement in the SYK model and in black holes was first proposed by Sachdev in 2010, and these connections have led to developments in the quantum theory of black holes.

## Experimental Implementations

Some variants of the model are amenable to digital quantum simulation, with pioneering experiments implemented in nuclear magnetic resonance.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.
